channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump’s Foray Into Venezuela Could Embolden Russia’s and China’s Own Aggression
item.description: While both countries were allied with Nicolás Maduro, the U.S. attack could give them justification to use force in other spheres, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Evgenia Novozhenina
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin last May. China and Russia both have close ties to Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: At the U.N., Even Allies Condemn U.S. Action in Venezuela
item.description: The deputy French U.N. ambassador said it chipped “away at the very foundation of international order.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting of the U.N. Security Council on Monday.

item.title: Venezuela Braces for Economic Collapse From U.S. Blockade
item.description: Venezuela could lose the bulk of its export revenues this year if the U.S. blockade stays in place, according to internal government estimates, a scenario that would set off a humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Employees outside Venezuela’s state oil company, known as PDVSA, in Caracas in October.

item.title: Stephen Miller Asserts U.S. Has Right to Take Greenland
item.description: In a CNN interview, the top Trump aide also echoed the president’s intent to run Venezuela as he laid out a case for the United States’ controlling weaker states by flexing its military might.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, the White House deputy chief of staff, at the White House last year. Mr. Miller’s remarks were part of a broader rhetorical push in interviews to justify American imperialism and a vision for a new world order.

item.title: Health Dept. to Freeze $10 Billion in Funding to 5 Democratic States
item.description: The funding pause could jeopardize child care and other programs that serve hundreds of thousands of households in California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Department of Health and Human Services spokesman cited “massive amounts of fraud” as the reason for the freeze, but did not provide evidence of fraud in four of the states.

item.title: RFK Jr. Scales Back the Number of Vaccines Recommended for Children
item.description: Federal health officials now recommend that children be routinely inoculated against 11 diseases, not 17, citing standards in other wealthy nations.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Laila Stevens for The New York Times
item.media:description: The number of vaccines recommended for American children will be reduced to 11 from 17.

item.title: Appeals Court Upholds Prohibition on Trump’s Medical Research Cuts
item.description: The ruling on Monday upheld a lower court’s judgment in April that the Trump administration could not drastically slash funding from the National Institutes of Health.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Hailey Sadler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal court of appeals ruled that the Trump administration could not cut federal funding given out by the National Institutes of Health.

item.title: For Many Jan. 6 Rioters, a Pardon From Trump Wasn’t Enough
item.description: Some pardoned rioters have been rearrested. Others returned to poverty and mental health challenges. And many became consumed by resentment and demands for payback.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Dan Barry
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Zelensky’s Assessment Darkens as Europeans Gather to Talk Peace
item.description: With Russia still seen as unlikely to stop fighting, the Ukrainian leader’s tone has shifted from upbeat to cautionary.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Tetiana Dzhafarova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine during a meeting of national security advisers of European countries in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Zelensky Taps High-Profile Canadian Politician as Economic Adviser
item.description: Ukraine’s president appointed Chrystia Freeland, a former deputy prime minister of Canada, to a role in which she would advise on postwar reconstruction, if peace talks are successful.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chrystia Freeland during an interview last year in Toronto.

item.title: Hegseth Starts Proceedings Against Sen. Mark Kelly Over His Remarks
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth blasted the senator for “seditious” remarks. Mr. Kelly said he had done nothing wrong and cited similar comments by Mr. Hegseth.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Our laws are clear. You can refuse illegal orders,” Senator Mark Kelly, Democrat of Arizona, said in a message to active-duty troops last year.

item.title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Votes to Shut Down
item.description: Executives debated whether to allow the corporation to lie dormant after federal funding ended last year, but decided against it.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Daniel Rosenbaum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patricia Harrison, president and chief executive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, in 2010. Congress last year voted to eliminate the organization’s $500 million in annual funding.

item.title: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz Abandons Re-election Bid, and Amy Klobuchar May Run Instead
item.description: Mr. Walz said a growing scandal over fraud in social services programs led him to abandon his run for a third term as governor of Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Reid J. Epstein and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Gov. Tim Walz said a widening scandal over fraud in social services programs in Minnesota had persuaded him to end his re-election bid.

item.title: Trump’s Post About Slain Minnesota Lawmaker Dismays Her Children
item.description: The son and daughter of Melissa and Mark Hortman have asked the president to remove a social media post promoting a conspiracy theory about the assassination.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sophie and Colin Hortman stood behind the caskets of their parents, Mark and Melissa Hortman, after a funeral service in Minneapolis in June.

item.title: Six Big Political Questions for 2026
item.description: A wildly important midterm year is off to a chaotic start, with a raid in Venezuela, an uneasy economy and more. Here’s what we’re curious about.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Trump rally in North Carolina last month.

item.title: Israel’s Stinging Retort to Mamdani Was Meant as Retaliation in Kind
item.description: After Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York scrapped two executive orders on antisemitism and boycotts, the Israeli Foreign Ministry issued an aggressive response to what it saw as an aggressive act.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York has long supported the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement against Israel over its treatment of Palestinians.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani Targets Junk Fees and Hidden Charges in Executive Orders
item.description: Trying to protect consumers by going after deceptive business practices has been an early focus of the new mayor’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.category: Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (NYC)
item.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani spoke at an outdoor gym in Hunter’s Point South Park in Queens.

item.title: Mamdani Chooses a Bernie Sanders Aide as His Communications Director
item.description: Anna Bahr, who leads communications for the Vermont senator and worked on his presidential campaign, is the latest appointee to a high-profile role in the Mamdani administration.
item.dc:creator: Sally Goldenberg and Benjamin Oreskes
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: Anna Bahr, center, the communications director for Senator Bernie Sanders, left, will leave his office to join the administration of Mayor Zohran Mamdani, right.

item.title: Nvidia Details New A.I. Chips and Autonomous Car Project With Mercedes
item.description: At the CES conference, Jensen Huang, the company’s chief executive, said the more efficient and powerful chip would begin shipping later this year.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nvidia’s Vera Rubin on display at a company conference in October. The new chip is named for an astronomer whose research supported the existence of dark matter.

item.title: At Refugee Camps, Most Birthdays Fall on New Year’s
item.description: When an exodus of Rohingya fled to Bangladesh a decade ago, the United Nations recorded many of their birthdays as Jan. 1. The date serves as a reminder of a lost identity.
item.dc:creator: Verena Hölzl
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees arriving in Bangladesh in 2017.

item.title: Waymo Has Come for the Kids in Los Angeles
item.description: Because families have complicated schedules.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll and Mark Abramson
item.media:description: Elle Shim, 17, and Ilyssa Freedland, 16, use a robotaxi to grab lunch during a break from ballet practice.

item.title: Dance Moves From the Street, City Edition
item.description: Dancers from Detroit, Chicago and Philadelphia demonstrate the fundamentals of their styles, revealing deep historical roots.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert and Vincent Tullo
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: Donald Trump Was Right to Oust Maduro
item.description: President Trump made a bold decision, and it was a stunning success.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Kroenig
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maxwell_Briceno/Reuters

item.title: Jamie Raskin: Jan. 6 Never Ended
item.description: Five years after Jan. 6, 2021, we are still caught up in a struggle over the meaning of that day.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Raskin
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Nate Gowdy

item.title: Hilton ‘Maliciously Canceled’ Immigration Agents’ Reservations, DHS Says
item.description: As the U.S. ramps up deportation efforts in Minnesota, the Department of Homeland Security claimed on social media that a Hampton Inn had canceled agents’ bookings.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scores of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents have been deployed in Minneapolis in recent weeks.

item.title: Eva Schloss, Anne Frank’s Stepsister and Holocaust Survivor, Dies at 96
item.description: Freed from Auschwitz, she was silent about her ordeal for four decades. Then she decided to dedicate her life to educating people about the dangers of prejudice.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Jae C. Hong/Associated Press
item.media:description: Eva Schloss in 2019. In a tribute, King Charles III lauded her for “overcoming hatred and prejudice” and for “promoting kindness, courage, understanding and resilience.”

item.title: Steve Sheetz, Who Popularized Convenience Stores as a C.E.O., Dies at 77
item.description: Sheetz, a family-owned company that started with a single convenience store in Altoona, Pa., has more than 800 locations in seven states.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Nic Antaya for The New York Times
item.media:description: The chain has more than 800 convenience stores in seven states.

item.title: Mamdani and Hochul Celebrate Congestion Pricing a Year After Contentious Debut
item.description: The tolling program, which charges motorists to enter Manhattan’s busiest streets, had a largely successful first year after a delayed start.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen and Winnie Hu
item.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, center, and Gov. Kathy Hochul, to his left, agree on the need for congestion pricing, but seem to still be apart on the mayor’s goal of making buses free.
